title: Spiegelhalter Introduction
text:
Question 1:



On page 9, the book doesn’t report the difference between the “low” happiness score for 50-54 year olds compared to the “high” score for the 70-74 age group. Make a guess for what the difference might be, based on your intuition. You don’t have to justify your guess.
  question id: S1-QB1-1 
Then, rereading the paragraph carefully to gather what facts are available, say what you think is the smallest difference between these groups that would be worth mentioning.
  question id: S1-QB1-2 








Question 2:



The reading lists some “necessary component[s]” of being a data scientists. List them, briefly.
  question id: S1-QB2 



S0-before.rmarkdown Collect your answers

No answers yet collected







Submit collected answers here

title: Spiegelhalter Chapter 4
text:
Question 1:



In discussing clinical trials, the book offers eight principles for a good study. List them by name and, for each, say whether or not you understand (or agree!) that the principle is important for drawing conclusions from data. Be honest! You don’t have to agree with David Spiegelhalter. And, insofar as you accept his authority on the matter, it is best to face head on any reasons you might have for skepticism.
  question id: S04A-1 








Question 2:



Traditional statistics course avoid issues of causation, other to warn students not to draw causal conclusions from observational—as opposed to experimental—data. Many of the modern ideas and methods concerning causality stem from the needs of epidemiology. What do you think it is about epidemiology that encourages an emphasis on causality?
  question id: S04B-2 








Question 3:



Explain in your own words what confounding variables, lurking variabiables, and covariates have in common.
  question id: S04B-3 








Question 4:



Explain in your own words what confounding variables, lurking variabiables, and covariates have in common.
  question id: S04B-4 



S4-before.rmarkdown Collect your answers

No answers yet collected







Submit collected answers here

title: Spiegelhalter Chapter 2 Follow-up
text:
Question 1:



Which three graphics in Chapter 2 use jittering?
  question id: S02A-1 








Question 2:



In Figure 2.5, there are three variables presented. Say what they are, which are categorical and which quantitative, and what graphical feature—x, y, facet—each is mapped to. Do you think the choice of the y-mapped variable is sensible as the response variable in a model, that is, which variable can be explained in terms of the other two variables.
  question id: S02A-2

title: Wide and narrow data
text:
Wrangling demonstrations. Cases where the variables are really levels of a variable

Spiegelhalter Fig 2.7


Another population dataset
For Fig 2.8 have them wrangle to get the proportion increase and then draw the graph using color for the relative size. Also, … what is the unit of observation? Are all the rows the same kind of unit of observation?

title: Reading Questions
text:
For instructors only



This document is intended for instructors as they create their day-to-day schedules. Those schedules will provide the student-facing link to reading-question documents.
Each of the six blocks in QR2 has assigned readings from Spiegelhalter, Rossling, and the computing tutorials. There are corresponding reading questions. These are organized by book chapter. Your instructor will indicate which questions are due and when.
Some of the reading questions should be completed and submitted before the date scheduled for the classroom discussion. Others are intended as follow up after the discussion. Due dates for the follow-up questions will be specified by individual instructors.
Note that some documents may be empty.

title: QR2 Winter 2025
text:
Under construction



To instructors: This is a draft of a shared homepage for QR2.

It lives in the QR2-W25 repository on Github.
The URL for students is https://qr2-w25.github.io/homepage/.
The link to paste into RStudio to clone the repo on your laptop is https://github.com/QR2-W25/homepage.git

title: QR2 Winter 2025
text:
Day-by-day schedule
There are six class sections for QR2. These follow a similar schedule, but naturally the viscisitudes and opportunities of classroom discussion lead to variation on a section-by-section basis. Accordingly, you should bookmark your section in your browser for easy access to the most up-to-date information.

Section 1 (Prof. Ruth)
Section 2 (Prof. Overbey)
Section 3 (Prof. Kolpakov)
Section 4 (Prof. Kaplan)
Section 5 (Prof. Puelz)
Section 6 (?)







In draft



The above list of sections is tentative. We should update it to reflect the actual section naming policy.
Depending on your preferences, you might want to replace your link(s) to point to another system, for example Google Sheets.
Danny has implemented a sketch of a schedule page in Quarto. Other instructors can draw on that as an example if they like. Each schedule should be placed in the QMD file with the indicated name. If you are using a different scheme for managing day-to-day class information, you may simply want to link to that in your QMD file. A throw-away example is in TBD-schedule.qmd.

title: QR2 Prof. Kaplan’s Section
text:
1. Tuesday 7 January, 2025



Orientation to QR2

Readings:

Spiegelhalter Introduction
Rosling Introduction
Note: As a rule, you should have completed a first pass of the day’s readings before the class meets. This being the first day, I can only ask to to try to do so.

Discussion:

Learning about data and statistics
Spiegelhalter Introduction
Rosling Introduction
Note: The items under the “Discussion” header in this document are just FYI. The readings and the reading questions are the appropriate preparation.

title: QR2 Prof. Kaplan’s Section
text:
Further out (i.e. tentative)






3. Tuesday 14 January, 2025



Block 1 (cont.)

New readings:

Computing tutorial 1: before class session
Rosling Chap 2 questions

Assignments due before class time:

Remember that the “New readings” section has links to the relevant reading questions.
For the computing tutorials, there are no “questions” as such, but be sure to run and, better, play around with the Active R Chunks. Then go through the familiar “Collect answers” and submission process. Your “answers” will be the contents of the Active R Chunks that you have run.
These principles apply to all class sessions, but won’t be restated explicitly in other day’s itemizations.

title: Gender-neutral names
text:
NOTE IN DRAFT



Point out that this will be just a demonstration. Use babynames as an inclass example of wrangling?

How can we figure out what are the most gender neutral names.
filter and summarize babynames: proportion of males and females with each name, select out those where the ratio is 0.25 to 0.75. Calculate the information (p ln(p))

title: Spiegelhalter Introduction
text:
Question 1:



On page 11, the reading refers to a “basic bag of [statistical] tools,” which is the focus of what the author claims is an outdated way of teaching about data science. What previous contact have you had with statistical tools that might be in such a “basic bag?”
  question id: S1-QB3
